header.title: The Demonic Apocrypha: Book II of the Demonic Bible
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Demonic Magic, Satanism

central_thesis: This grimoire presents a complete system of Black Magic, building upon the rituals of the first Demonic Bible. It aims to guide the Satanist in navigating the Qlippoth and the Kingdoms of the Black Earth, enabling them to enter into a Covenant with Satan and manifest the Power of Hell through the manipulation of the objective universe via the collective subconscious, driven by will, faith, desire, and precise principles. The core philosophy emphasizes radical individualism, self-deification, and a rejection of conventional religious dogma, aligning with the concept of man becoming 'as gods'.

structure_content.summary: Introduces the book as Book II of The Demonic Bible, detailing rituals developed over 10 years, focusing on Qlippoth and the Black Earth. It posits that all gods are man-made and corrupt, defining Greater Black Magic as manipulating the objective universe through the collective subconscious using will, faith, desire, and principles. The book serves as a grimoire for covenanting with Satan and manifesting infernal power.

The author, a 25-year Satanist, asserts Satanism is a religion of certainty, not faith, where God is a symbol of defiance. Written for Satanists, it dispenses with arguments on Satanic philosophy, recognizing no genuine conflict between various Satanic currents (LaVeyan, Spiritual, Luciferian, Setian, LHP). It argues that the Devil, as an Inverse Deity or archetype, may exist as a thought-form or pre-exist man. The chapter concludes with a call for unity among a fragmented global Satanic community.

Defines all magic, particularly effecting change by will, as 'satanic' and Black Magic. The author recounts a personal 'crossing of the abyss' experience, revealing a 'twilit world' without God or Satan, reinforcing the reality of unseen realms. It critiques the omnipotent creator as ultimately corrupt and views Jesus Christ as a 'great Satanic Master,' embracing a world where 'all gods are daemons'.

Explains 'Aeonic Word' as a conceptual expression, linking it to figures like Crowley and Aquino. A covenant is defined as a pact implying sovereignty and equality, seen in Abrahamic religions (paradoxically LHP) and the Witch's pact with Satan. The concept extends to social contracts, emphasizing man's equal standing with divine forces once gnosis is attained, making him 'as gods' rather than subservient.

The author's metaphysical view describes God and Satan as existing beyond conventional imagination. It outlines dimensions from 0D to 6D, where the 5th dimension is the individual psyche and the 6th unifies all psyches. Reality is subjective, shaped by belief; thus, 'whatever we believe true, becomes true.' Self-realization through 'thesis/anti-thesis/synthesis' leads to 'gnosis' or 'Awakening.' The author shares his personal 'gnosis' experience, identifying as an 'antichrist, servant and disciple of the Dark Lord'.

Introduces Aleister Crowley and his dictation of Liber Al vel Legis (The Book of the Law), which established the Aeon of Horus. Excerpts from Chapter I, II, and III are provided, outlining key Thelemic principles such as 'Every man and every woman is a star,' 'Love is the law, love under will,' the nature of Nuit and Hadit, the rejection of traditional morality, and the call for the chosen to assert their will and embrace ecstasy. Ritualistic instructions for worship and sacrifice are also included, emphasizing the prophetic role and future revelations.

Details Jack Parsons' 1946 ritual, which resulted in the dictation of LIBER 49 from BABALON, considered an extension of Crowley's Book of the Law. Excerpts from LIBER 49 reveal Babalon's intent to manifest in flesh, calling for adherents to offer everything at her altar and to undertake the 'Black Pilgrimage.' The text describes rituals involving specific tools, attire, and invocation methods, promising power, joy, and conquest over death and Hell. It also includes the 'Manifesto of the Antichrist,' proclaiming the end of Christianity's hypocrisy and the establishment of the Law of the Beast 666.

Discusses Charles Robert John Stansfeld Jones (Frater Achad), who declared the Aeon of Ma'at as succeeding the Aeon of Horus. 'Liber Pennae Ultim-Atum' is presented, a complex mystical text referencing Egyptian deities (Atum, Tefnut, Shu, Maat, Thoth), Qabalistic concepts (Kether, Chokmah, Binah), and Eastern philosophy (Yin, Yang, Maya). It details the cosmic process of creation, division, and reunification through symbols like the Eye, Serpent, and Arrow of Art, emphasizing the return to source and the balance of existence.

Focuses on Anton Szandor LaVey, founder of the Church of Satan, and his initiation of the Age of Satan. Excerpts from 'The Book of Satan' ('Might Is Right') are included, vehemently rejecting traditional religion, morality, and weakness. It advocates for strength, self-preservation, and vengeance, declaring a 'death for the dogs' and a world for the strong. LaVey's Nine Satanic Statements are listed, promoting indulgence, vital existence, undefiled wisdom, and gratification over conventional sins.

Introduces Michael A. Aquino, founder of the Temple of Set, who received the 'Book of Coming Forth By Night' (BCFBN) from Set. This chapter outlines Set's revelation, establishing the Aeon of Set to succeed Horus and the Age of Satan. Set, identified as the ageless Intelligence and Hebrew Satan, criticizes LaVey's Church of Satan while restoring LaVey's Magus status. The text emphasizes the importance of Set's pentagram, the pursuit of Setian knowledge by 'the Elect,' and direct, fearless communication with Set. It includes a hieroglyphic symbol and the concept 'Xeper = Become'.

Presents a multi-part revelation from Set, delivered in Enochian-like text with English translations. Set proclaims himself 'the Highest of Life,' a source of perfection, truth, and power for humanity. He calls upon 'Guardians' and 'Elect' to embrace their divine potential, defy death, and build civilization infused with His essence. The Word describes the Cosmos as a cycle of life and death, highlights the dangers of annihilation, and urges the Elect to manifest their strength against those who worship death, ensuring their endurance and glory in the dawning Aeon.

Authored by Magus Tsirk Susej, presenting himself as 'Antichrist, servant & disciple of the Dark Lord,' embodying the Dragon and one with Father Satan. He claims to have returned after death to lead the people of Shaitan, guiding them to destroy enemies and become Gods. The book outlines a path of self-indulgence, pleasure, and eternal deathlessness, despising peace and love for adversaries. It details specific invocation rituals involving 'red water of life' and warns against vain invocation. The author claims to bring true knowledge from the 'Ancient of Ancients' for those who walk in darkness, enabling them to survive destruction and become gods on Earth.

Describes the Qlippothic Tree as ten spheres opposing the Tree of Life's sephiroth, referred to as 'evil twins' and 'Evil Demons of Matter.' It also lists seven Infernal Habitations (hells), twelve Qliphotic orders of demons, three powers before Samael, and twenty-two Genii (demons) corresponding to Hebrew letters. Each Qliphothic sphere is detailed with its opposing sephirah, its demonic order (e.g., Thamiel for Kether, Chaigidel for Chokmah), and attributed demons (e.g., Satan, Moloch, Beelzebub, Lilith), defining their destructive or chaotic nature.

Argues that identity often stems from tribal affiliation (Christian, Jew, Satanist), driven by a need for inclusion and separation. The author criticizes the irrationality of 'right' religions and the conformity within occult groups, advocating for individual truth-seeking over dogma. He highlights that 'group mind' is a powerful thought-form for large religions and even for 'Aeons' in occult contexts, but warns against blind adherence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Concerning the Dangers of Black Magick
structure_content.summary: Stresses self-analysis and critical thinking in Black Arts, noting that societal conditioning influences perception. The author shares his 'abyss' experience and defines magic as a process of self-discovery and 'becoming' (Xeper), leading to 'deitus' or manifestation as a god. He critiques external dogmas in magical practices, urging practitioners to extract principles and create their unique systems rather than parrot existing rituals, acknowledging magic as potentially 'the science of the future' with an element of wonder.

structure_content.chapter_title: Concerning the Death of Tsirk Susej
structure_content.summary: The author reflects on self-criticism and his decision to step away from a successful organization to prevent its corruption, acting as 'Magus of the Aeon of Lucifer.' He describes an 'intense emotional need to alter the course of events' that felt right for himself and the aeon, despite making enemies. This decision, though subjective, was a deliberate act of leadership during a critical period of magical evolution.

The author explores how even perceived freedom is influenced by early conditioning, sharing his childhood experience of rejecting Christianity as a result of his mother's skeptical views, realizing that 'not believing' was as much a product of conditioning as belief itself. This illustrates the deep-seated nature of psychological imprints on one's worldview and spiritual path.

Challenges the notion of historical 'facts' as subjective and biased. The author advocates for creating one's 'own history' based on personal conviction. He leans towards accepting Jesus' literal existence as a powerful magician and a 'Satanic priest' who challenged the religious establishment, viewing him as a 'heretic and reformer, a revolutionary,' contextualizing him within ancient esoteric traditions rather than mainstream religious narratives.

Argues that due to mutual exclusivity, most, if not all, religious beliefs are incorrect. The author dismisses the pursuit of absolute religious truth as futile, advocating instead for living life fully and questioning all established beliefs, including within the LHP. He acknowledges daemons as archetypes/thought-forms, recognizing the incompleteness of human knowledge. The author posits that subjective belief shapes reality and that the LHP's unique advantage lies in the ability to doubt and question received reality.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Brief History of the Church of Satan
structure_content.summary: Provides a timeline of the Church of Satan and its spin-off organizations, beginning with Anton LaVey's 'Magic Circle' in the 1950s and the founding of the CoS in 1966. It details key events such as the publication of 'The Satanic Bible,' the formation of the Temple of Set by Michael Aquino in 1975, leadership changes involving Diane, Zeena, and Karla LaVey, and later developments including Peter Gilmore's appointment as High Priest and the shifting policies regarding the grotto system.

Describes the author's personal 'Greater Black Magic' ritual on the 1999 Winter Solstice, aimed at conjoining various aeonic currents (Set, Horus, Maat, Khepera/Lucifer). The working involved a four-fold aeonic matrix and recitation from key texts like Crowley's 'Book of the Law' and Aquino's 'Book of Coming Forth By Night,' along with the author's own 'Book of the Covenant.' The ritual focused on spoken 'Words' (Xeper, Deitus, Xem, Remanifestation, Runa, Heart, Essent, Unity, Nox, Kaos) to expand consciousness and consolidate various magical currents, envisioning a future where man becomes god or perishes by 2011.

Analyzes the historical and mythological foundations of Abrahamic religions, tracing their roots to Sumerian, Phoenician, Canaanite, and Egyptian influences. It highlights the syncretic nature of deities (El, Baal, Adonai, Yahweh) and the pagan origins of various traditions, including the solar cult of Akhenaton, the Mithraic parallels to Christ, and the integration of Gnostic teachings into early Christianity and Islam. The author argues that Biblical narratives, like those concerning prophets and magic, reflect earlier pagan practices, challenging the unique authority of these traditions and emphasizing the subjective nature of religious truth.

Discusses the author's theory of the Fourth Covenant, a concept derived from Thelemic thought and elaborated in this book. It categorizes historical spiritual movements into four covenants: ancient Hebrews/Magi, Gnostic Christians/mystery schools, mystical Islam, and the current Fourth Covenant encompassing Aeons of Horus, Satan, Maat-Magick, Set, Chaos-Magick, and Lucifer. Satan (Set-hen) is defined as the dynamic consciousness and principle of isolate intelligence. The covenant signifies an agreement between equals, with man achieving 'god-like' status through gnosis, correcting the 'corrupted' RHP understanding of covenant as subservience.

key_concepts.definition: The manipulation of the Objective Universe by the agency of the Collective Subconscious and by application of cause and effect in the Subjective Universe, requiring Will, Faith, Desire, and the proper application of principles.
The Devil/Satan, understood not as an object of worship but as a symbol of defiance against man-made gods, representing carnality, the psyche, and the inverse of God in all nations and times.

An expression of a core concept or formulation of a Law for an age, such as 'Thelema, Xeper, Deitus' (Will to come into being as a God), representing shifts in consciousness or worldviews that are subjectively real and influential.
The Word of the Aeon of Set, meaning 'to become' or 'to come into being,' representing the expansion of consciousness and the rebirth of the psyche, analogous to the rising sun (Khefe-Ra).

The author's discovered Word for the Aeon of Lucifer, meaning 'Will to come into being as a God,' representing the potential for man to define himself as a god through the application of his Will to the expansion of his psyche.

Literally 'shells,' referring to 10 spheres in opposition to the sephiroth of the Tree of Life, also called 'evil twins' or 'Evil Demons of Matter and the Shells of the Dead.' They represent chaotic or destructive aspects of divine energies and are associated with various demonic orders.

A foundational myth where Fallen Angels (Watchers), led by Satanael (Lucifer), gained self-consciousness, defied the Demiurge (tyrant God), and imparted forbidden knowledge and arts of civilization to humanity, elevating man to 'godhood' through a 'Daimonic Seed'.

A ritual concept from LIBER 49 by Babalon, requiring the adherent to offer all, withhold nothing, be 'smitten full sore,' and become an 'outcast and accursed, a lonely wanderer in abominable places,' implying a profound transformative journey.

Crowley's Word of the Law, 'Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law,' interpreted not as personal freedom for desires, but as obedience to the magician's Higher Self or Holy Guardian Angel (True Will), seen as a resolve to pursue the 'Great Work'.
A Word meaning 'to become visible,' associated with the sun in its rising or the psyche in its awakening, linked to the concept of Essent (gnosis) and the broader Aeonic philosophies.

practical_system.description: The system presented is a practical grimoire of Black Magic, designed for self-deification and the manifestation of infernal power. It builds upon the 'Demonic Bible' (Book I) rituals for 'Crossing the Gates of Hell' and uniting with 'Forces of Darkness,' expanding into the Qlippoth and Black Earth realms. The core operative principle is 'Greater Black Magic,' manipulating objective reality via the collective subconscious through Will, Faith, Desire, and precise application of principles. The author emphasizes personal gnosis and creating a unique magical system, rejecting dogmatic adherence to pre-existing rituals while drawing heavily from established LHP traditions. The goal is to achieve 'deitus' (will to become a god) through the 'Xeper' (becoming/expansion of consciousness) process, realizing one's sovereignty and equality with divine forces through a Covenant with Satan.
tools: Egyptian Ankh (for navigation in the Abyss)
Copper disk (3 inches diameter, painted blue with a gold star of Babalon, for Babylon Working)
Silver or gold (to burn on the altar)
Oil of Abramelin and olive oil
Meal, honey, thick red wine, fresh blood (for ritual cakes and perfumes)
Stele of revealing (with an image of Set)
Setian Pentagram (as a personal talisman and for magical vision)
rituals: Rituals for Crossing the Gates of Hell and becoming one with the Forces of Darkness (from Book I).
Rituals for traversing the Qlippoth and the Kingdoms of the Black Earth (focus of Book II).
Invocation of Satan: 'spill the red water of life upon the earth and chant my name nine times' to ensure appearance and receive 'my mark'.

Sacrifice and Offerings (from Liber AL vel Legis): includes 'fresh blood of a child' (though 'not now'), 'blood of the moon' (menstrual blood), blood of enemies, priests, worshippers, or beasts. These are burned, made into cakes to eat, or laid before the altar to become 'full of beetles...and creeping things'.
Rituals for War and Attack: Slaying enemies by name to make them 'fall before you,' breeding 'lust & power of lust' by eating sacrificial cakes.

The Babylon Working (from LIBER 49): Involves specific offerings (all of oneself, withholding nothing), using sandalwood perfume, green and gold cloth, a cup, dagger, and a copper disk painted with Babalon's blue field and gold star. A 'Black Pilgrimage' is implied for the adept.

Aeonic Current Conjunctions (e.g., Winter Solstice VII Working): An elaborate Greater Black Magic ritual to unite various aeonic currents (Set, Horus, Maat, Khepera/Lucifer) within a four-fold matrix, involving recitations from The Book of the Law, The Book of Coming Forth By Night, and the author's own Covenant texts. Key 'Words' (Xeper, Deitus, Xem, Remanifestation, Runa, Heart, Essent, Unity, Nox, Kaos) are spoken to expand consciousness and align magical forces.

Setian Invocation: Speaking to Set 'as a friend, gently and without fear,' typically at night, without bending the knee or dropping the eye, shunning recitation of others' texts, and using the magic of the Setian pentagram to perceive through Set's eyes.

relevant_quotes.text: This is a Complete Grimoire of Black Magic which will allow the reader to enter into a Covenant with Satan and to Manifest the Power of Hell.
If power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely, the omnipotent creator of heaven and earth must be the most evil son-of-a-bitch who ever lived.

Greater Black Magic is the manipulation of the Objective Universe by the agency of the Collective Subconscious and by application of cause and effect in the Subjective Universe. This requires Will, Faith, Desire, and the proper application of principles.

Whatever we believe true, becomes true, as we are our own gods and there is really nothing beyond thought. But, if I believe in God and Satan, then God and Satan are real. If I believe in Jupiter, Zeus, and Athena, then they are real. It is all a question of perspective.

Logically, the Devil may or may not exist. If He exists, it may be as a powerful thought-form or as a product of the Collective Subconscious (this I suggest in the first book of the Demonic Bible.) The Devil may, however, pre-exist man as a being distinct from the universe. Set is considered one of the Neters of ancient Egypt in Setian or Sethian Philosophy. Whatever the Devil may be, we are drawn to Him as the archetype of carnality and of the psyche. This is what defines us as Satanists and which separates us from agnostic atheist humanists or eclectic pagan hedonists.
The Demonic Bible began with the premise that all gods are created by man and that a devil is simply an unpopular god.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant within Western Esotericism and Occultism as it directly engages with and attempts to synthesize core concepts from Thelema (Crowley), Setianism (Aquino), and LaVeyan Satanism, presenting a cohesive 'Fourth Covenant.' It provides a unique perspective on the historical evolution of Satanic and LHP thought, interpreting foundational texts like 'The Book of the Law' and 'The Book of Coming Forth By Night' within a broader, unified framework. The author's personal gnosis and experiential approach, alongside his critical analysis of religious conditioning and subjective reality, contribute to contemporary discourse on magical efficacy and the nature of deity. The extensive detailing of the Qlippoth and their corresponding demonic entities offers a valuable technical reference within Qabalistic studies from an LHP perspective.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is primarily practicing Satanists and advanced practitioners of the Left-Hand Path, particularly those familiar with Thelemic, Setian, and LaVeyan philosophies. The book explicitly states it is 'written for Satanists rather than non-Satanists.' It assumes a familiarity with its predecessor ('The Demonic Bible') and delves into complex metaphysical concepts and ritualistic components that would be challenging for novices. Academics studying modern occultism and syncretic magical traditions would also find it valuable for its comprehensive overview and integration of various LHP currents.
